description.narrative: Mainstreaming Conservation of Migratory Soaring Birds into Key Productive Sectors Along the Rift Valley/Red Sea flyway
To ensure that globally threatened and significant populations of soaring birds that migrate along the Rift Valley/Red Sea flyway are effectively maintained.
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration

Conservation management objectives and actions for MSBs are mainstreamed effectively into the hunting, energy, agriculture, waste management and tourism sectors along the Rift Valley/Red Sea flyway, making this a safer route for soaring birds
1. Number of new and revised country sector policies (hunting, energy, agriculture, waste management and tourism) incorporating MSB issues approved by national governments

comment.narrative: 0 policies at start of year 1
A total of at least 6 sector policies approved by end of year 5

Total Policies 14 with 9 in progress
Egypt:
Total remains 4 policies and 1 in progress
Update on previous policies
MoU between EEAA and NREA was renewed on Jan. 2015 to consider conservation of MSBs at wind farm projects along the Red sea flyway.
The waste water company request the MSB project to join the protocol : An extension to the protocol was prepared by MSB project and signed from minister of environment, south Sinai governor and the project and sent to the waste water treatment company for signing.
In progress:
An MoU between EEAA and Tourism development Authority (TDA) is still waiting for signing as all parties agreed on the content of the MoU
Jordan
New Total (2 + 1 new policies) and 2 remain in progress
New Policy
Hunting: The new Agriculture Law (including revised hunting provisions) was passed on 16 April 2015 & published in the Official Gazette on 16 May 2015. Implementation of revised agriculture law for regulation of hunting has started with the new violation fines and penalties as set by RSCN.
Update:
Raptor MoU: All documents have been submitted to the Mminister of Environment. They have been reviewed and set to be signed by end of July.
Lebanon:
New total is 5 ( 3 + 2 new policies) while 3 remain in progress
New policies
1. Convention on Migratory Species Raptor MOU signature 28/12/2014 by the Minister of Environment
2. National Physical Land Use Plan (NPLP). Updates regarding all IBAs, bottlenecks and protected areas as an extra GIS layer of the NPLP was adopted by the CDR ( council of development and reconstruction), as they agreed to add a new category named “bird sensitive areas” where all necessary measures of bird protection will take place for any upcoming project specially in the fields of agriculture, construction and energy. Official letter was forwarded from CDR to the urban civil organization directorate (ministry of public works) to address this issue. Date: 10/03/2015 ref number 1/969
Regional
New total is 2 (1 + 1 new policy) while 3 remain in progress (see 2014)
New Policy
1. Syria signed the Raptor MOU signature 24/12/2014 by the Minister of Environment

description.narrative: 2. Number of new private sector projects and schemes incorporating MSB concerns in each target sector

comment.narrative: 0 projects at start of year 1
At least 4 among participating countries by end of year 5

Cumulative Total:
11+1 = 12 projects and same 8 still in progress
Egypt: No change (6 projects)
Jordan
4+1 = 5 Projects and 5 remain in progress.
Energy: At the Tafila region, BirdLife partner in Jordan, RSCN is cooperating with the International Finance corporation IFC in the Cumulative Impact Assessment – CIA of the Tafila region (including 4 wind farm projects) were a Steering Committee of was established to overlook the CIA with IFC & it’s technical partners along with BirdLife & RSCN
Lebanon
No change ( 1 project + 1 in progress)
Regional
NO Change (2 in progress)

description.narrative: 3. Annual application of GEF BD2 tracking tool shows increased scores throughout life of project

comment.narrative: Score at beginning of year 1 = 0 out of 30
Increased score at each yearly review of project up to end of year 5.

The GEF BD2 tracking tool document was prepared for the mid-term review.
The score at Mid-Term of the project is 12 out of 30

description.narrative: 4. Land managed for hunting, energy, agriculture and waste management under â€˜flyway sensitiveâ€™ practices at selected sites (bottlenecks) along flyway

comment.narrative: 0 ha at beginning of year 1
15% by end of year 5 compared to project start baseline

Cumulative Total: 217,939.4 ha EgyptAdditional 30,000 ha. A strategic EIA at the Gabal al Zeit area for 300 Km2 (30000 ha) to produce 1500 MW addressed MSBs consideration by recommending the application of shutdown on demand system for all new wind energy development. Lebanon Update Signature of hunting management and RHA’s ethical code by 8 Heads of municipalities and municipality unions, that were gathered in a special session to launch the final RHA maps based on the criteria proposed by SPNL and reviewed by the MOE. The maps were created in cooperation with Balamand university. Surface area in ha to be calculated

description.narrative: 5. Number of sites with â€˜flyway sensitiveâ€™ practices along flyway

comment.narrative: 0 at start of year 1
At least 10 bottleneck sites by end of year 5

Cumulative total: 16
Egypt
Update
Gabel Al Zeit: EIA study performed for the Gabel Al Zeit area recommended usage of shutdown on demand practices for all new wind development.
Jordan
Update
The four bottleneck sites are covered by the new patrolling plan that reduced illegal activities such as falconry across these areas
Lebanon
8 sites in progress
Signature of hunting management and RHA’s ethical code by 8 heads of municipalities and municipality unions, that were gathered in a special session to launch the final RHA maps based on the criteria proposed by SPNL and reviewed by the MOE.

description.narrative: 7. Increase in number of hunters and tour guides able to identify specific soaring birds and name activities that threaten them operating at selected bottleneck sites

comment.narrative:
Number of hunters and tour guides aware of MSB issues at start of year 1

Syria: 0% hunters; 0% of tour companies
50% increase in numbers of hunters and tour guides aware at end of year 5 compared to year 1 baseline figures

Lebanon (no change):
6 Hunting Groups
325 Hunters
Jordan:
The 1500 hunters that renewed their license have received the Code of Best Practices for Responsible Hunting publication developed by the project.
Eco-guides (no change) 22
Egypt:
3 training workshops for 70 tour guides were hold at sharm el-sheikh and Ras Mohammed bottle neck site. The training was both theoretically and in the field.

Egypt:
2 new requests
1. Request from NREA for the project to share its experience and expertise by participating in the feasibility study workshops for a new KFW project and Emirates company (Massdar) wind farm project at Gabel al-Zayt (GZ) bottleneck.
2. A new request from the Civil airports to guide them on how they can solve the conflict between Migratory birds and airplanes.

description.narrative: Increased national and regional capacity to effect double mainstreaming and application of Flyway concept (Tranche I and II)
10. Capacity of national partners to apply double mainstreaming as indicated by BirdLife-UNDP capacity assessment score

comment.narrative: Partner capacity assessment scores at end of PDF-B phase
At least 7 partners with capacity assessment scores of over 18

Final MSB Project Tranche I 2015 Capacity Development report indicated 7 project partners scored over 18, they are:
Jordan : RSCN
Saudi Arabia: SWA
Palestine: PWLS
Syria: SSCW
Sudan: SWS
Djibouti: ADN
Ethiopia: EWNHS
While 3 project partners fell behind the score, they were:
Yemen: FEW
Egypt: NCE
Lebanon: SPNL

description.narrative: 11. Increase in number of joint national project partner-government and project partner-private sector partnerships established in key sectors during project period to achieve mainstreaming of MSB concerns

comment.narrative: Jordan 1 relevant partnership; Palestine 4; Lebanon 4; Ethiopia 0; Egypt no data; at 2005
2005 figure + 3 by end of year 5 for each national partner

Cumulative total: 22
Jordan
2 new partnerships
RSCN is partnering with the International Fund Cooperation (IFC) as it sits on the advisory committee for the Cumulative Impact Assessment for the Tafila region financed by the IFC.
RSCN is collaborating with the Jordan Tourism Board in the development of a national strategy for birdwatching.
Lebanon
Update on partnership with Minister of Interior and internal security forces:
New bird identification and hunting law training was delivered by Dr. Ghassan Jaradi (ornithologist) to the internal security forces members the workshop took place daily between 27 February and 1 April 2015 the overall number of individuals trained was 400.

description.narrative: Content and tools to enhance flyway friendly practice developed, delivered and mainstreamed effectively into sector processes and programmes ( Trenches I and II)

comment.narrative:

Lebanon: 350 soaring birds sold in known markets in 2004 (real total much higher)

Jordan:
Update
Illegal Trading is now increasingly taking place via internet and e-commerce tools. Monitoring of the internet led to the confiscation of 5 MSBs that were displayed on the social media tools.

WASTE MANAGEMENT:
17. Number of EIAs for new waste management projects that address MSB concerns in project area and along Red Sea coast of Egypt

comment.narrative: 0 EIAs that address MSBs in 2004-2005
At least 3 new EIAs address MSBs by end of year 5

No Change

description.narrative:
WASTE MANAGEMENT:
18. Number of existing waste management sites where â€˜flyway friendlyâ€™ best practice measures have been adopted

comment.narrative: 0 sites in 2005
At least 2 pilot sites by end of year 5

Cumulative Total: 2 sites
No Change
The Sharm Sheikh waste water treatment ponds is now a bridwatching attraction. The project has catalyzed the inauguration of a birdwatching tower overlooking the ponds. The project conducted a tour guide training course for birdwatching at the site in coordination with its management authority.

description.narrative:
ENERGY:
19. Planners take account of bottlenecks in national and local energy planning

comment.narrative: 0 countries
In at least 2 countries by end of year 5

Total remain 4 Countries
Update ( 2 countries in progress):
Lebanon
Update
As reported above, an extra GIS layer of the NPLP was adopted by the CDR ( council of development and reconstruction), covering “bird sensitive areas” where all necessary measures of bird protection will need to be taken into account in upcoming projects specially in the fields of agriculture, construction and energy. Ethiopia
During the World Migratory Birds Day 2015, an event was organized by EWNHS that included discussions with local energy planners & a visit to an operating wind farms. The authorities showed openness to discuss mainstreaming bird conservation into the sector.
Syria
During the World Migratory Birds Day 2015, an event was organized by SSCW that included the planners of energy projects at the Syrian Investment Map. The MSB project guidance was introduced & the Ministry of Environment showed interest to update its EIA regulations to include MSB considerations.

description.narrative:
ENERGY
20. New energy projects adopt best practice in avoidance and mitigation of MSB risks

comment.narrative: 0 countries
For at least 5 projects by end of year 5

Cumulative Total: 7
Egypt
Update
Shutdown in demand was included in the recommendations of the EIA report of a Gabal al Zeit windfarm for an area of 300 Km2 to produce 1500 MW for new wind energy development.

description.narrative:
ENERGY
21. Collaborative monitoring schemes in place at existing and new energy projects to assess mortality rate

comment.narrative: 0 countries
Monitoring protocols designed and tested for at least 2 projects by end of year 5 with stakeholder participation/endorsement

Cumulative 2 projects + 4 in progress
Egypt
(remains 1 scheme + 1 in progress)
Update on Post Construction Monitoring at Gabal Al Zeit
2014 Autumn survey of the PCM monitoring program at Gabal Al Zeit (on non-operational wind farm) found 19 dead white pelicans that collided with transmission lines.
2015 Spring survey on the same site (still non-operational) found no dead soaring birds.
Field training was delivered to Nature conservation section of EEAA and nature conservation Egypt (BirdLife partners)and local communities on bird identification, Carcasses search and collision risks at wind farm sites.
Jordan
(remains 1 scheme + 3 in progress)
The Tafila Wind Project now installed its wind turbines. The project is still committed to run a post construction monitoring after full operation. The MSB Pproject along with RSCN & IFC are currently involved in a Cumulative Impact Assessment of the 4 projects in Tafila region (including Tafila Wind Project) and the other 3 (at various pre-establishment stages at the moment) will be expected also to run a post construction monitoring after operation.

description.narrative:
ENERGY
22. Mitigation of any high-levels of mortality at existing sites that may be identified during the project

comment.narrative: 0 countries
High risk sites with significant mortality identified by end of year 5

Egypt
Update
Shutdown on Demand will be adopted at Gabal Al Zeit after being included in EIA report recommendations.

description.narrative:
TOURISM
23. Number of locations with demonstration of benefits to tourism sector from MSB activities

comment.narrative: 0 countries
At least 5 tourist locations at end of year 5

Cumulative Total remains 11 and 2 in progress
No Change
Due to the war that recently broke out in Yemen, plans for the Bab Al Mandedb bottleneck sites have temporarily freezed.
In Jordan negotiations are still taking place to integrate birdwatching infrastructure and activities in the dead sea panorama.

description.narrative:
AGRICULTURE:
24. Number of agriculture development plans incorporating MSB conservation considerations

comment.narrative: 0 agriculture development plans
At least two agriculture development plan by end year 5

The MSB project finalized agriculture guidance material and worked closely at the higher level of BirdLife and its international partners (e.g. the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds – RSPB in the UK) to build up of the CMS endorsement of it at the highest possible level. Eventually, the CMS CoP 11 held in November 2014 took its UNDEP CMS Resolution 11.15 on “Preventing Poisoning of Migratory Birds” that was officially published in January 2015.
Meanwhile, the Sudanese Wildlife Society (SWS) through cooperation with the governmental body of the “Plant Protection Directorate” continue to mainstream the agriculture guidance at the national levels and presented a proposal to focus its efforts on this sector in Tranche II of the project.
Moreover, EWNHS continues to seek national partnerships in the country through close coordination with the Pesticide Action Nexus Association ( PAN Ethiopia) and the Horn of Africa Regional Environment Centre & Network at Addis Ababa University

description.narrative:
AGRICULTURE:
25. Number of agricultural projects incorporating MSB conservation considerations

comment.narrative: 0 projects
At least one project by end year 5
DAL agricultural company in Sudan (leader in agricultural projects in the country) is now in close working relationship with SWS to incorporate MSB conservation considerations in its activities

description.narrative: Learning, evaluation and adaptive management increased
26. Lessons learned from demonstration activities applied to other sites along the flyway

comment.narrative: 0 demonstration sites at start of year 1
Lessons learned applied to at least 5 other sites along flyway by end of year 5

Cumulative Total: 5 sites
With 2 new sites:
Lebanon
Hunting
The hunting management in control in Kfarzabd and in Niha is now replicated in the town of Anjar that is now leading the way to present a pilot site as a Responsible Hunting Area in Lebanon with Anjar Municipality allocating the land for this purpose and start agreement on details with SPNL.
Jordan
Energy
In cooperation with IFC, the cooperation between RSCN & the Tafila Wind project is now entering a higher level through the participation of the 3 new adjacent wind farm projects in a joint Cumulative Impact assessment funded by IFC.

description.narrative: 27. Positive monitoring and evaluation reports, both internal and external

comment.narrative: First evaluation report (first 6-monthly BirdLife report)
BirdLife and GEF-UNDP Mid-term Evaluations and reports at end of Tranche I show positive reports

The Mid-term Review took place in October 2014. The report indicated the successes of the project and recommended to proceed into Tranche II of it.
The MTR report noted after scrutinizing all aspects and achievements through detailed inspection visits to the 3 tranche I countries that all triggers to continue in Tranche II of the project have been successfully met.

description.narrative: 28. Targets for project and partner entry into Tranche II verified

comment.narrative:
1. Baseline of 0 at start of year 1
2. Baseline of 0 at start of year 1
3. Baseline of 0 at start of year 1
4. Baseline of 0 at start of year 1 (existing information poor or non-existant)

1. 4 of the 6 double mainstreaming pilots in Tranche I successful
2. 1:3 GEF:co-financing ratio secured for Tranche II
3. Agreement with at least one new reform vehicle for Tranche II
4. Establishment of material links between sector activity and bird mortality along the flyway and the establishment of baseline data against which impact indicators can be measured verified by UNDP-GEF, in accordance with GEF criteria

1 The Mid-term Review indicated the success of 4 mainstreaming pilots in Tranche I of the MSB Project
2 BirdLife secured the requested GEF co-financing of $10.5 million for Tranche II
3 Agreement for 9 vehicles in Tranche II were reached, they are:
2 in Agriculture in Sudan & Ethiopia
3 in Tourism in Palestine, Lebanon & Egypt
2 in Hunting in Lebanon & Syria
1 in Energy in Egypt
1 Land-use planning (cover 4 sectors) in Jordan

title.narrative: Mainstreaming biodiversity conservation in tourism secto

description.narrative: Biodiversity conservation objectives are effectively mainstreamed and advanced into and through tourism sector development in Jordan

title.narrative: Mainstreaming biodiversity conservation in tourism secto
Mainstreaming biodiversity conservation in tourism secto
Mainstreaming biodiversity conservation in tourism secto

description.narrative: Biodiversity conservation objectives are effectively mainstreamed and advanced into and through tourism sector development in Jordan
capital of a political entity
Energy - policy, planning and administration
Biodiversity Conservation Objectives are Effectively Mainstreamed and Advanced into and through tourism sector development in Jordan
Consideration of biodiversity in plans and policies for tourism development by government, planning authorities and the private sector

comment.narrative: No explicit reflection of biodiversity priorities
At least 80% of known and available plans and policies for tourism development incorporate biodiversity priorities

20% achieved
At this point, biodiversity is not clearly depicted in the tourism policies and plans. However, MoTA incorporates general environmental protection and eco-friendly practices with focus on lowering water and energy consumption and using renewable energy resources.
The achieved 20% is based on the following facts:
A green unit has been recently established to serve as a policy tool to mainstream green practices particularly in relation to biodiversity conservation.
Furthermore the new investment Law No (30) for the Year 2014, which gave a clear and direct highlight on the role of Jordan Investment Commission ( JIC) in protection of the environmental, water resources, natural resources, and biodiversity in line with the environmental law, regulations and instruments and in close coordination with the relevant bodies.
It’s important to mention that The National Tourism Strategy (NTS) 2011-2015 is a private sector-led with public sector partnership. The strategic objective of the Pillar 4, Enabling Environment, is to “Enhance Jordan’s business, operational, regulatory, environmental and institutional settings to underpin the drive for improved competitiveness” which gave a clear and direct highlight on the importance of environment and sustainability by adopting initiatives that protect and preserve the environment.
The project is currently assessing existing legal and institutional setups with attempt to identify policy gaps to be addressed later.

description.narrative: Level of consideration for biodiversity conservation in tourism development proposals

comment.narrative: While energy and water feature in environmental considerations at present, biodiversity does not
100% of proposals for tourism development consider biodiversity conservation seriously

To date 5% of the new proposals for tourism development considers biodiversity explicitly. In preparation to achieving this target, the project has been working hardly on establishing green unit under the umbrella of MoTA; the unit has been approved by the minister and private sector board to be added to the existing structure. As per the preliminary design of the unit, it will be attached to licensing and classification department to ensure proper integration of biodiversity considerations in all new tourism proposals. As soon as it comes to function, the percentage will considerably increase.

description.narrative: Hectares of landscape where impacts on biodiversity are avoided, mitigated or offset

comment.narrative: No planning provisions for the protection of biodiversity outside formal PAs
Some 180,000 hectares covered by biodiversity-friendly land-use plans effectively preventing impact on biodiversity

91,659 hectares.
Total of 17,459 hectares in Petra Landscape covered by comprehensive land use plan that considers biodiversity component. Of which 11,900 hectares covered by PAP Buffer land use plan, the plan aimed at ensuring the integrity of the ecological, cultural and archeological values within the Petra archeological Park (PAP).
Tow expansion areas have been covered by land use plans that also ensure the integrity of the ecological, cultural, and natural values within Petra landscape. With a total area of 5,559 hectares.
The project will pursue its effort to enhance the enforcement of the policies and regulatory frameworks as related to land use planning within Petra land scape.
Wadi Rum area; a total area of 74,200 hectares is covered by zoning plan within Rum PA as part of the master management plan. The whole management plan and its zoning plans designed to conserve the ecological and cultural values.
The project concluded the consultation phase with ASEZA and other concerned stakeholders to identify and prioritize the land use planning priorities, based on which it was decided to address the issue of developing a comprehensive land use plan for the buffer zone of Rum that addresses the ecological values and integrity of the protected area. The sought land use plan should insure the sustainability of natural and cultural assets of Rum protected area and maintaining associated ecosystem services. The new land use plan will cover another 60,000 hectares.
Given the complications of land use planning component across the three sites and provided that there are existing ongoing initiatives, the project started with extensive scoping assignment in order to understand the current situation and to identify possible incremental support in each site that complements and builds on existing land use practices. The scoping study revealed the gaps and priorities in each site, it also resulted with priority interventions in each site, for instance it was revealed the buffer zone of Rum PA is a top priority as far as the biodiversity conservation is conserved. The study included deep analysis of legal set up, institutional set up, technical and human capacities, data management, and existing monitoring regimes.

description.narrative: Total annual revenue earned from tourism operations in targeted PAs

comment.narrative:
Dibeen Forest Reserve: US$ 43,000
Wadi Rum PA: US$ 976,467
Shoubak Proposed PA not yet established

An increase of 50% or more to the following levels –
Dibeen Forest Reserve: US$64,500
Wadi Rum PA: US$1,464,700
Shoubak Proposed PA: at least 50% of its operating costs at least in the beginning

Dibeen Forest Reserve: $37,100 during the reporting period, this represents 13% decrease in the total revenue. This is partly attributed to the overall dramatic decline in number of visitation coming into the country because of the political situation in the Middle-east
Wadi Rum PA: $564,200 during the reporting period.
This is partly attributed to the overall dramatic decline in number of visitation coming into the country because of the political situation in the Middle-east.
Petra PA: $3,920,400 will serve as a base line level for Petra PA, an increase of 50% or more to this level during the next reporting period.

description.narrative: Regulatory and enforcement framework in place to avoid, reduce, mitigate and offset adverse impacts of tourism on biodiversity
The place of biodiversity in the legal and procedural framework for tourism planning, development and operations

comment.narrative: Biodiversity considerations are currently absent from the framework.
Biodiversity element/s are integrated/incorporated in the legal and procedural framework for tourism planning, development and operations

The project continued its effort to assist MoTA in the process of revising the legal and institutional frameworks by conducting a comprehensive and critical review of the existing legal and institutional set ups, the assessment revealed that, currently there is poor reference to issue of protecting the natural heritage and biodiversity in the tourism related legal framework under the Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities. Most of the provisions of laws and regulations only enforce protection to archeological sites and lack for natural heritage aspect. There is a genuine opportunity to modify the legal framework of the tourism sector embarking on the recently reactivated council, so called the "Higher Tourism Council" based on Article (5) under the tourism law, the council, that includes a representation of the MoEnv, is responsible for setting the general policy of the sector and its strategies as well as setting modifications for the regulations. The project will continue working with the council to mainstream biodiversity friendly tools and instruments.
A green unit has been recently established to serve as a policy tool to mainstream green practices particularly in relation to biodiversity concentration.

description.narrative: Application of the new Biodiversity-friendly guidelines for the EIA Process

comment.narrative: No such guidelines exist
All new developments / hotels / roads/ etc apply new Biodiversity-friendly guidelines for the EIA Process

0
This will be developed based on biodiversity-friendly tourism legal framework review which will include a set of biodiversity standards developed, tested, and adopted for the MoTA certification schemes for hotels, eco-tour operators, eco-lodges and environmental camp sites. Based on this review a certification schemes for Hotel, eco-tour, eco-lodge and environmental camp sites will be developed, tested, and adopted by MoTA, according to the new schemes this indicator will be measured. Furthermore, The project has also succeeded in creating what so called "Green unit" within MoTA for the first time, Green unit will be a key player in mainstreaming biodiversity and environmental issues within MoTA, and will effectively contributed to enhance the environmental culture within MoTA employees and among decision makers, the project managed the discussion with MoTA and tourism private sector and other relevant stakeholders to approve the establishment of the "Green Unit".

description.narrative: Percentage of tourism establishments in project localities that are biodiversity-friendly according to the MoTA Certification Scheme

comment.narrative: At least 50%

0
This will be developed based on biodiversity-friendly tourism legal framework review which will include a set of biodiversity standards developed, tested, and adopted for the MoTA certification schemes for hotels, eco-tour operators, eco-lodges and environmental camp sites. Based on this review a certification schemes for Hotel, eco-tour, eco-lodge and environmental camp sites will be developed, tested, and adopted by MoTA, according to the new schemes this indicator will be measured. Furthermore, The project has also succeeded in creating what so called "Green unit" within MoTA for the first time, Green unit will be a key player in mainstreaming biodiversity and environmental issues within MoTA, and will effectively contributed to enhance the environmental culture within MoTA employees and among decision makers, the project managed the discussion with MoTA and tourism private sector and other relevant stakeholders to approve the establishment of the "Green Unit".

description.narrative: Institutional capacities for planning, monitoring and enforcement strengthened in Jerash, Petra and Wadi Rum landscapes/development zones, so as to manage the impacts of tourism development on biodiversity within ecologically valuable and sensitive areas
Extent of land area for which integrated land-use plans that deliver biodiversity benefits outside PAs are developed and under implementation

comment.narrative: Current land area covered by biodiversity-sensitive LUPs is nil
180,000 hectares covered by integrated land-use plans

91,659 hectares.
Petra site; Total of 17,459
Wadi Rum area; a total area of 74,200
Given the complications of land use planning component across the three sites and provided that there are existing ongoing initiatives, the project started with extensive scoping assignment in order to understand the current situation and to identify possible incremental support in each site that complements and builds on existing land use practices. The scoping study revealed the gaps and priorities in each site, it also resulted with priority interventions in each site, for instance it was revealed the buffer zone of Rum PA is a top priority as far as the biodiversity conservation is conserved. The study included deep analysis of legal set up, institutional set up, technical and human capacities, data management, and existing monitoring regime.
Total of 17,459 hectares in Petra Landscape covered by comprehensive land use plan that considers biodiversity component. Of which 11,900 hectares covered PAP Buffer land use plan, the planned aimed at” Transforming the concept of development in land use plan from pure physical construc¬tion and development to controlled oriented Activities, within an overall compromised management planning framework to achieve the different required levels of protection while achieving also the required socio-economic development”
Tow expansion areas have been covered by land use plan that also ensuring the integrity of the ecological, cultural, and natural values within Petra landscape. With a total area of 5,559 hectares.
The project will pursue its effort to enhance the enforcement of the policies and regulatory frameworks as related to land use planning within Petra land scape.
The project concluded the consultation phase with ASEZA and all concerned stakeholders to identify and prioritize the land use planning priorities, based on which it was decided to address the issue of establishing a comprehensive land use plan for the buffer zone of Rum that addresses the ecological values and integrity of the protected area. The sought land use plan should insure the sustainability of natural and cultural assets of Rum protected area and maintaining associated ecosystem services. The new land use plan will cover another 60,000 hectares.

description.narrative: Capacity development indicator score for mainstreaming biodiversity in Jordan

comment.narrative: Overall score: 43%
Overall score: 60%

A percentage will be given at the Midterm Evaluation phase.
However, this score is enhanced through project intervention within the three sites, for instance the establishment of the GIS/Web-based data base/ information management system will facilitate reporting and monitoring on the status of biodiversity in all project sites.
Furthermore, the project conducted significant efforts to provide adequate training program to fulfill management objectives to the project site teams, two main training programs were conducted during reporting period, the first training program dealt with management plans development and implementation and involved 20 participants from RSCN, PDTRA and ASEZA/Rum PA, mainly aimed at:
Understand the added value and benefits of biodiversity management in and around cultural World Heritage sites;
Know how to access and use additional guidance and resources on biodiversity management in a World Heritage context;
The second training program was focused on “Protected Area Regulations and Legislation Enforcement”, it was aimed at instructing course participants about law and regulations that govern management and operation of protected areas, including law enforcement”, and involved six participants from ASEZA/Rum, PDTRA and RSCN/Dibbin.
As a results of the conducted training. PA teams are equipped now with the knowledge and the skills that enable them to conduct a simple, participatory, CMP Open Standards based PA management planning process on their own.
Moreover, two participants are working now with international consultant in order to develop integrated management plan for Petra site.

description.narrative: Increase in land area where threats to ecologically sensitive areas from tourism activities are controlled

comment.narrative: 0 ha

Jerash Governorate: Aleppo Pine (Pinus halepensis) Forests 6,200 ha. Petra Region: Hisheh Forest (Quercus coccifera) 300 ha. Wadi Rum Landscape: Sand Dune vegetation (Haloxylon persicum) type – 8,900 ha

830 hectares in Aleppo pine forest.
In case of Aleppo pine forest, in an attempt to reduce adverse impact from tourism activities on the forest, the project supported the design of a new alternative picnicking site, the new site once constructed will be used for heavy tourism activities, by this the Aleppo pine forest will be given the opportunity to rehabilitate and relax with much less tourism pressure. The project managed to leverage extra financial resources from the Royal Court to fund the construction phase of the alternative site.
The first phase of the land use planning component was a preparatory phase in which a comprehensive analysis for the current situation in all project sites was done, based on this review an action plans and major gaps were identified. The second phase will be informed by the first phase and will cover 60,000 hectares as a buffer zone for Wadi Rum PA which will include the Sand dune vegetation (8,900 ha), and will positively affect the conservation of this important vegetation type.
For Hisheh site, based on the first phase showed that PDTRA was intensively working on the land use activities recently, the project intervention in the second phase will be focused on the legal and enforcement levels, the current land use plans suggest Hisheh area as a green area.

description.narrative:
Populations of the following indicator species across the landscape (inside and outside PAs) remain stable:
Jerash Governorate: Lacerta media
Petra: Vulpes cana
Wadi Rum: Caracal caracal

comment.narrative: Baseline populations
No decrease over baseline values

The project started with extensive fauna and flora surveys in the three sites, the surveys aim produce up to date eco-values zonation maps in association with social values and geological values for the three sites. And to assess the current situation of these key species, The collected data will be used in the other hand to update the contents of the Biodiversity Information Management System (BIMS) and to setup the monitoring indicators.
The project will develop a monitoring program for the key species in each site including theses important ones.
The project has significantly contributed to achieve this target through the establishment of the GIS/Web-based data base/ information management system. The system will facilitate reporting on the status of biodiversity in all project sites including the three species.

description.narrative: Level of credibility of licensing and permitting authorities who sanction and regulate tourism developments

comment.narrative: Survey to confirm and document credibility level in the eyes of stakeholders (primarily the tourism sector)
Enhanced credibility of licensing and permitting authorities as a result of an improved basis for decision-making arising from sound data and information and effective monitoring system

0
The project is in process of finalizing biodiversity information management system (BIMS) which is GIS-web- based system. The BIMS is meant to establish sound data and information and effective monitoring system at the regional level, it will also serve the land use planning purposes by offering reliable data and information for NHS layers, and ultimately for licensing and permitting procedures. It important to mention that local and national authorities would have access to BIMS to be used for more reliable decision making..
On the other hand, the establishment of the green unit within MoTA will sever as a national monitoring and control system for new tourism developments, based on which the MoTA will be enabled to make decisions properly.

description.narrative: Improved management effectiveness particularly in revenue generation, tourism planning and management, and community relations in Dibeen, Shoubak and Wadi Rum Protected Areas
METT scores in each of Dibbin, Wadi Rum and PAP PAs

comment.narrative:
Scores obtained during PPG are:
Dibeen 58%
Wadi Rum 67%
PAP to be determined
Improvements expected in effectiveness in revenue generation, tourism planning and management and community relations, leading to an improvement in METT scores of around 8-10%.

This indicator will be measured at the Midterm Evaluation phase.
However, this score enhanced through project intervention within the three sites, the establishment of the GIS/Web-based data base/ information management system. The system will facilitate reporting and monitoring on the status of biodiversity in all project sites including the three species.
Furthermore, the project conducted significant efforts to provide adequate training program to fulfill management objectives to the project site teams, two main training programs were conducted during reporting period, the first training program dealt with management plans development and implementation and involved 20 participants from RSCN, PDTRA and ASEZA/Rum PA,
The second training program was focused on “Protected Area Regulations and Legislation Enforcement”, it was aimed at instructing course participants about law and regulations that govern management and operation of protected areas, including law enforcement”, and involved six participants from ASEZA/Rum, PDTRA and RSCN/Dibbin.

description.narrative: Financial security and sustainability of PAs

comment.narrative: The three PAs (less so with Wadi Rum) currently rely almost entirely on government grants and/or development aid as sources of finance
Increase the level of financial resources that are generated on site (and not reliant on government budget or development aid) to 50%

No substantial progress.
However, for the case of Rum, the new management plan emphasized on enhancing financial sustainability. It was recommended to develop a standalone business plan with aim to diversify and increase sources of income.
Business planning for Rum PA is planned to take place in the second half 2015.
The three PAs still rely almost entirely on government grants, little changes have occurred in the reporting period.
The political unrest in the region represents causes a dramatic decline in tourism sector. Most of the tourism sites in Jordan (including PAs) experience serious reduction in visitor’s number with less financial resources collected
